Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SusChEM: Phase-specific catalysis combined with reactive distillation for the selective production of butadiene from y-valerolactone

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1605114 / 1605071
PIs: Bond, Jesse Q. / Crossley, Steven P.
Title: Collaborative Research: SusChEM: Phase-specific catalysis combined with reactive distillation for the selective production of butadiene from y-valerolactone

Economically feasible conversion of biomass to chemicals is of critical importance for sustainability. Inherent inefficiencies in alkane activation and production gaps caused by the recent shale gas boom have created niches within the petrochemical industry that might realistically be filled by biomass. The goal of this collaborative project is to develop a new technology for selective production of a relatively high-value petrochemical, butadiene, from aqueous solutions of gamma-valerolactone, a biomass derived chemical. The butadiene markets have become increasingly volatile after the recent paradigm shift in refinery operation. The researchers will develop a multiphase reactor to achieve selective butadiene production from aqueous solutions of gamma-valerolactone.

The envisioned chemical transformation occurs through sequential ring opening of valerolactone to form pentenoic acid isomers, which subsequently undergo decarbonylation to form butadiene. A multiphase reactor will be employed to achieve ring opening of valerolactone to form pentenoic acids in an aqueous phase, extraction of these pentenoic acids into an organic phase, decarbonylation of pentenoic acids in the organic phase to form butadiene, and reactive distillation of butadiene from the organic phase to a sweep gas. Fundamental studies of the governing phenomena will be undertaken in order to develop strategies for maximizing butadiene selectivity. The aim will be to integrate non-ideal solution thermodynamics, phase and chemical equilibria, reaction kinetics, and transport phenomena into an overall process model and functional reactor design. This approach will also lead to a better fundamental understanding of condensed phase catalysis and multiphase reactors. In addition to training graduate students, the PIs plan to engage high school and undergraduate students in their research and develop an educational module on biomass refining.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project has been to provide an on-purpose means of converting bio-based gamma-valerolactone (GVL) into dienes.  In particular, we have targeted the production of butadiene and pentadiene. Diolefins are critical in the production of synthetic rubbers and a variety of other chemicals. They have historically been produced as a byproduct of ethylene production via naptha cracking for; however naptha cracking is declining with the increasing availability of low-cost shale gas and the consequent improved economics of ethane cracking. This has created a gap in diene supplies, which incentivizes their production from alternate resources and through alternate technologies. As a polyfunctional molecule, biogenic GVL is a potentially attractive precursor to diolefins.

Producing dienes from GVL, a lactone, requires a combination of opening a 5-membered heterocyclic ring (a lactone) and selective hydrodeoxygenation, decarbonylaton, and/or dehydration of the resultant unsaturated carboxylic acids (pentenoic acids).  Numerous such sequences can be envisioned leading from GVL to butadiene and pentadiene, and all are generally constructed around ring opening and selective hydrodeoxygenation of a carboxylic acid.

We have been identified that Lewis acidic solid oxides facilitate near-equilibrium yields of pentenoic acids during vapor-phase GVL ring opening. Importantly, these materials do not induce undesired side reactions, like decarboxylation, to the same extent as Bronsted acidic materials. We have additionally considered low-temperature, liquid-phase, ring opening of GVL in biphasic reactors.  Here, we attempted to exploit variation in solvent identity and composition to mitigate severe equilibrium limitations on the endothermic ring opening of GVL at low temperatures. This research resulted in a thermodynamically and kinetically rigorous model for biphasic reactors, which is an improvement over empirical treatments of biphasic systems, which typically do not resolve the thermodynamic and kinetic consequences of solvation. We believe this will provide a better description of exactly how solvation impacts macroscopic process metrics like rates, yields, and selectivities and can thus inform solvent selection in liquid phase and biphasic reactors.

In terms of selective oxygen removal, we have demonstrated that bimetallic catalysts that pair platinum group metals with oxophilic promoters deliver near-quantitative selectivity to alcohols during the HDO of carboxylic acids by eliminating decarbonylation and CO inhibition, both of which plague carboxylic acid HDO on monometallic Pt and Ru catalysts. Unfortunately, the bimetallic formulations face two challenges in practical implementation.  First, they are expensive due to the inclusion of platinum group metals.  Second, they always retain activity for C=C saturation, which results in the conversion of alkene acids to 1-alcohols instead of alkenols.  While this can be used as a technology for producing a-olefins, it is nonviable for producing diolefins. We therefore developed two alternate routes for the production of diolefins from alkene acids. The first is based on reverse Mars van Krevelen chemistry on reducible oxides for the selective conversion of carboxylic acids into aldehydes and alcohols. The second route is based on intermediate trapping of the carboxylic acid in an ester form, which can then decarbonylate selectively over base metal catalysts without saturation of the diolefin. We have additionally demonstrated that tin oxides allow selective esterification of pentanoic acids with aliphatic alcohols, while avoiding the undesirable formation of ethers catalyzed by Bronsted acids.

This project has provided training for 3 PhD students and 2 MS students at the University of Oklahoma and Syracuse University. Students involved have participated in annual hands on summer camps aimed at encouraging first generation and minority students to pursue engineering. Research efforts aimed at solid acid characterization and analysis of biphasic systems have supported 8 peer-reviewed publications to date. An additional 3 ? 6 collaborative manuscripts between OU and SU describing recent work aimed at production of diolefins in gas and liquid phase processes are anticipated beyond the completion of this project.
